body.p: The October issue of Nutrition in Clinical Practice is dedicated to the nutrition approach to cancer. In this issue of CAM Corner, we introduce the concept of integrative oncology and the integrative approach to cancer prevention.

sec.title: Integrative Oncology
sec.p: There is a growing trend of people who are seeking an approach to medicine and health care that is comprehensive, holistic and integrative, and compassionate and sensitive to their needs as a whole person. More than ever, people are flocking to complementary and alternative modalities (CAM) for disease prevention and management.1 A December 2008 report by the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS)2 indicated that 38% of all Americans use some form of CAM. This is particularly true for cancer, which carries an uncertain life expectancy and much fear. In the United States, 1 in every 2 males and 1 in 3 females will be diagnosed with cancer at some point in their lifetime. Thus, Americans are becoming more conscious of what behaviors and factors may increase their risk of cancer. No other diagnosis has been associated with such widespread use of CAM utilization by patients than cancer. Studies indicate that up to 80% of all cancer patients use some form of CAM during the course of their illness.3 People with cancer are motivated to use CAM to improve survival, improve quality of life, decrease adverse effects from chemotherapeutic agents, and alleviate mental, emotional, and spiritual pain and anxiety. The issue of emotional distress and anxiety is important to overcome in managing cancer care.4 This has led to the widespread use of multiple modalities to approach stress management in cancer patients.

sec.title: Integrative Approach to Cancer Prevention
sec.p: An individual’s risk in developing cancer revolves around the interaction of environmental influences that alter the expression of oncogenes. Conventional approaches to cancer risk include diet and physical activity, behavioral modification, medications, surgery, and vaccinations. It is generally accepted that a high intake of fruits and vegetables is beneficial for cancer prevention because of their associated increased concentrations of fiber, antioxidants, and other phytonutrients.5,6 Maintaining a healthy body weight is important for cancer prevention as obesity is known to predispose people to a number of cancers. Likewise, alcohol consumption has also been linked to numerous cancers, and overconsumption should be avoided. The American Institute for Cancer Research7 has recommended individuals to be as lean as possible within the normal range of body weight, incorporate physical activity into everyday life for at least 30 minutes daily, and limit alcoholic drinks to 2 for men and 1 for women daily. The American Institute for Cancer Research warns against the use of nutraceutical supplements to “protect” against cancer.

sec.title: The Role of Diet in Cancer Prevention
sec.p: The risk of a number of cancers has been tied into the consumption of specific foods. For example, low fruit and vegetable intake has been associated with an increased risk of bladder, breast, and distal colorectal cancer.8-10 Diets that are high in saturated fats have been linked to a number of solid tumors such as breast, prostate, colorectal, lung, and gallbladder cancer.11,12 However, interventions aimed at significantly reducing dietary fat have not shown substantial benefit. For example, in the Women’s Health Initiative, a randomized trial of dietary fat reduction that was the largest and most expensive study ever conducted, no significant effect was seen for the incidence or mortality of breast cancer, any other type of cancer, or total cancers.13,14 A number of possible dietary carcinogens should be avoided or at best consumed in moderation. These include foods contaminated with toxins produced by molds (eg, aflatoxin) and foods rich in processed meats containing nitrites.15 Red meat consumption has been linked to colorectal, breast, and prostate cancer.16-18 Grilling meat raises the risk as does cooking meat at high temperatures, such as in pan frying, grilling, or cooking over an open flame. Meats charred during cooking produce heterocyclic amines, and meat cured with salt during preparation also raises the risk of cancer. Trans fats have been purported to be associated with colorectal, breast, and prostate cancer, whereas ω-3 fatty acids have anticancer properties. Thus, the emphasis should be substituting less healthy fats (ie, trans fats) with more healthy fats (ie, ω-3 fatty acids) rather than reducing the total fat intake. The Mediterranean diet, which promotes ω-3 fatty acids and limits red meats and saturated fats, has been associated with reduction in cancer risk.19-21

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: There are abundant data on the role of diet in the promotion and prevention of cancer. The American Institute for Cancer Research7 has provided board-based recommendations to reduce the risk of cancer, such as eating a variety of fruits and vegetables daily, limiting consumption of energy-dense foods and sugary drinks, limiting consumption of red meats and avoiding processed meats, and limiting the intake of salty foods and foods processed with salt. The American Cancer Society (ACS)22 recommends a healthy diet with an emphasis on plant-based foods. The ACS further recommends limiting red and processed meats, choosing whole over refined grains, and eating at least 2½ cups of vegetables and fruits each day.
